messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] RE: sew a doll snugli
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, they are easy to make.  I d suggest making them longer though. They can be used in so many other areas of play and can be used for a long time, unless
messages.messageBody:
Yes, they are easy to make. I'd suggest making them longer though.
They can be used in so many other areas of play and can be used for a
long time, unless they are too small.

Joylyn

Krisula Moyer wrote:

>
> I made a sling (not a snuggli) It's easy. Just hem the outsides of a
> rectangle *aprox*. the same length as your daughter's arms, fingertip to
> fingertip.
> Fold one end through two craft rings (can be plastic, wood or metal)
> and sew
> closed. Done.
>
> To wear, tuck the free end through the rings and pull to desired size.
>
>
> Krisula

messages.subject: RE: sew a doll snugli
messages.msgSnippet: I made a sling (not a snuggli)  It s easy.  Just hem the outsides of a rectangle *aprox*. the same length as your daughter s arms, fingertip to fingertip. Fold
messages.messageBody:
I made a sling (not a snuggli) It's easy. Just hem the outsides of a
rectangle *aprox*. the same length as your daughter's arms, fingertip to
fingertip.
Fold one end through two craft rings (can be plastic, wood or metal) and sew
closed. Done.

To wear, tuck the free end through the rings and pull to desired size.


Krisula



Original message:
Date: Sat, 27 Mar 2004 05:27:38 -0800 (PST)
From: Sharon Rudd <bearspawprint@...>
Subject: Re: Digest Number 1221


Sew Baby Patters has them

Sharon of the Swamp



Subject: doll accessories

Does anyone know where to buy, or pattern for making, a snugli style baby
carrier for a doll? Jackie wants one for her *baby*.

Thanks!
